Comparing Lord of the Flies to Hitler's Regime and the Holocaust by Maria Langstaff. Characters and situations in Lord of the Flies have many similarities to Hitler's Nazi regime and the persecution of the Jews which led to the Holocaust.

"The Dehumanization of Piggy and also the Jews: Hitler found power at a time when Germany had been at an all-time low. Jack does significantly the same thing, waiting until the particular boys had been bored as well as restless below Ralph's command, after which coming forward along with enticing all of these with speak regarding entertaining and games and hunting when they produced him their chief (Golding 146). Just Like Hitler, Jack would always be a great orator, and utilized his charm to persuade another boys in order to his point associated with view (Adolf Hitler Biography)." [sic]

Connections between Nazism and the Lord of the Flies. YouTube video, 2:37 min. Uploaded on Oct 5, 2008 by Onawa Powell through Professor Rev. Dr. James Kenneth Powell II, opensourcebuddhism.org. "In this work, we see connections between various types of 'mobbing': from the bully Jack to Hitler, humans seem to stack up to insecure bullies picking on the different, and inciting other insecure sub-bullies to make it happen overall. Thankfully, there are types like Simon and Wallenberg who restore our faith in the capacity of at least some heroic individuals to overcome adversity."

Lord of the Flies: DVD Release - Synopsis. Directed by Peter Brook. Rating: R. imdb: 6.2. Runtime: 91 min. Theater date: Mar 16, 1990. Theater gross: $14.0 mil. Genre(s): Adventure, Drama, Thriller. No parents. No teachers. No rules ... No mercy. Overview: A group of boys from an all-boys' school crashes on an uncharted island. Their pilot is dead, so it is up to them to figure out how to survive. Ralph emerges as an early leader, while Jack begins to challenge his authority, showing a dark streak that another particularly malicious boy feeds into. As paranoia builds, the boys imagine that there is a god on the island, and Jack begins to create dark rituals surrounding this deity. A gentle boy named Simon and the bespectacle Piggy, a chubby boy who suffers from asthma, stand by Ralph in his quest to retain reason and order in their little society, but they are quickly losing control. Can they survive long enough to get rescued and return home?

Students will also plan, design and compose a diary entry that demonstrates their ability to evaluate these online sources. These are the steps you will take in order to complete the Webquest assignment:

● 1. Research information about the lives and evacuations of children in England during WW2.

● 2. Watch videos about the evacuations and take notes.

● 3. Collaborate information with group members and discuss findings.

● 4. Choose a character and write a two page diary entry based on their life before the island using the information that you researched.

What is some of the symbolism in "Lord of the Flies"? (Note: What are some ...)

Best Answer - Chosen by Asker:

● First, the conch - a symbol of leadership, authority. Why? Used to call assemblies. The person holding it was granted the floor to speak.

● Spears - ability to hunt, provide, savagery, danger, murder. Why? Once spears were created, boys were then armed.

● Fire - rescue, warmth, hearth, comfort, light, food (cooking.) Why? Obvious. Fire has been a necessity and comfort since it was discovered.

● Pig's head on a spear - The Lord of the Flies. The Devil. Evil. Savagery in us all. Why? The boy hunters, reveling in their kill, stuck the pig onto the head and Simon, during an epileptic episode hallucinated the pig speaking to him, saying evil things. The dead pig represented killing.
